Literature Review: Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) and the Experience Sampling Method (ESM) have revolutionized the way researchers capture real-time data on individuals' experiences, behaviors, and psychological states in their natural environments. These methods offer a dynamic alternative to traditional retrospective self-reports, which are often plagued by recall biases and inaccuracies. However, as the use of EMA and ESM has expanded, several pressing issues have emerged that warrant careful consideration to ensure the validity, reliability, and applicability of these methods. This literature review evaluates nine critical issues in EMA research, drawing on recent studies to highlight challenges and propose directions for future research. One of the primary concerns in EMA research is the extent to which participants accurately report their momentary experiences. Studies have shown that individuals may struggle to detach from their broader emotional states or contextual influences when responding to momentary assessments, potentially compromising the validity of the data collected (Shiffman et al., 2008). Furthermore, the interpretation of momentary questions by respondents can vary significantly, influenced by individual differences in cognitive processing and emotional states (Stone & Shiffman, 1994). This variability underscores the need for clear and unambiguous question phrasing in EMA studies. Another issue is the use of comparison standards in responding. Participants may inadvertently compare their current state to an atypical baseline, leading to biased responses (Kahneman et al., 2004). Efforts to extend the EMA reporting period beyond the moment to longer periods within a day have been explored as a way to capture more comprehensive data. However, this approach raises questions about the trade-off between data richness and participant burden (Conner & Lehman, 2012). Training of EMA study participants is another critical factor that can influence data quality. Adequate training can enhance participants' understanding of the EMA process and improve compliance, but the optimal training methods and duration remain areas of active investigation (Bolger & Laurenceau, 2013). Selection bias is a pervasive issue in EMA research, as the characteristics of individuals who choose to participate may differ from those who do not, potentially limiting the generalizability of findings (Trull & Ebner-Priemer, 2013). The impact of missing EMA assessments is another significant concern, as missing data can lead to biased estimates and reduced statistical power. Strategies to minimize missingness and handle missing data effectively are crucial for the integrity of EMA studies (Little & Rubin, 2002). The reliability of momentary data is also a topic of debate, with some researchers questioning the stability of constructs measured over short intervals (Cranford et al., 2006). Finally, the question of for which purposes EMA might be considered a gold standard for assessment is complex. While EMA offers unparalleled insights into real-time experiences, its suitability as a gold standard may vary depending on the research question and context (Shiffman et al., 2008). In conclusion, addressing these nine issues is essential for advancing the field of EMA and ESM. Future research should focus on developing standardized protocols, enhancing participant training, and exploring innovative methods to mitigate biases and improve data quality. By tackling these challenges, researchers can unlock the full potential of EMA and ESM to provide deeper insights into human behavior and psychological processes.
